Keywords.documentation: Identifies a line as a comment line. Same as the !, $*, and REM statements.
Inserts and compiles UniVerse BASIC source code from another program into the program being compiled. Same as the $INCLUDE and INCLUDE statements.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the #INCLUDE statement to direct the compiler to insert the source code in the record program and compile it with the main program. The #INCLUDE statement differs from the $CHAIN statement in that the compiler returns to the main program and continues compiling with the statement following the #INCLUDE statement.

Keywords.documentation: Identifies a line as a comment line. Same as the *, !, and REM statements.
Inserts and compiles UniVerse BASIC source code from another program into the program being compiled.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the $CHAIN statement to direct the compiler to read source code from program and compile it as if it were part of the current program. The $CHAIN statement differs from the $INCLUDE statement, #INCLUDE statement, and INCLUDE statement in that the compiler does not return to the main program. Any statements appearing after the $CHAIN statement are not compiled or executed.

Keywords.documentation: Inserts comments into the object code header. (UniVerse supports this statement for compatibility with existing software.)
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the $COPYRIGHT statement to specify copyright information in UniVerse BASIC object code. copyright.notice is inserted in the copyright field at the end of the object code.

Keywords.documentation: Defines a compile time symbol.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the $DEFINE statement to define identifiers that control program compilation. $DEFINE has two functions: 1) Defining an identifier 2) Supplying replacement text for an identifier

Keywords.documentation: Begins a new page in the listing record. (UniVerse supports this statement for compatibility with existing software.) Same as the $PAGE statement.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the $EJECT statement to begin a new page in the listing record.

Keywords.documentation: Tests for the definition of a compile time symbol.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the $IFDEF statement to test for the definition of a compile-time symbol. $IFDEF tests to see if identifier is currently defined (that is, has appeared in a $DEFINE statement and has not been undefined).

Keywords.documentation: Tests for the definition of a compile time symbol.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the $IFNDEF statement to test for the definition of a compile-time symbol. The $IFNDEF statement complements the $IFDEF statement.

Keywords.documentation: The $INCLUDE\$INSERT directive inserts the program/code snippet specified into the current source code. If the optional filename is specified the code is read from that file.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the $INCLUDE statement to direct the compiler to insert the source code in the record program and compile it with the main program. The $INCLUDE statement differs from the $CHAIN statement in that the compiler returns to the main program and continues compiling with the statement following the $INCLUDE statement.

Keywords.documentation: Performs the same operation as $INCLUDE; the only difference is in the syntax. (UniVerse supports this statement for compatibility with existing software.)
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the $INSERT statement to direct the compiler to insert the source code contained in the file specified by primos.pathname and compile it with the main program. The difference between the $INSERT statement and $INCLUDE statement (and its synonyms #INCLUDE and INCLUDE) is that $INSERT takes a PRIMOS path name as an argument, whereas $INCLUDE takes a UniVerse file name and record ID. The PRIMOS path is converted to a path; any leading *> is ignored.

Keywords.documentation: In NLS mode, specifies the map for the source code.
Keywords.snippetDoc: In NLS mode, use the $MAP statement to direct the compiler to specify the map for the source code. Use the $MAP statement if you use embedded literal strings that contain non-ASCII characters.

Keywords.documentation: Sets compile time emulation of UniVerse flavors.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the $OPTIONS statement to set compile-time emulation of any UniVerse flavor. This does not allow object code compiled in one flavor to execute in another flavor. You can select individual options in a program to override the default setting.

Keywords.documentation: Begins a new page in the listing record. (UniVerse supports this statement for compatibility with existing software.) Same as the $EJECT statement.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the $PAGE statement to begin a new page in the listing record.

Keywords.documentation: Removes the definition for a compile time symbol.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the $UNDEFINE statement to remove the definition of identifiers set with the $DEFINE statement. The $UNDEFINE statement removes the definition of identifier from the symbol table if it appeared in a previous $DEFINE statement. If the identifier was not previously defined, $UNDEFINE has no effect.

Keywords.documentation: Identifies a line as a comment line. Same as the !, $*, and REM statements.
Returns an escape sequence used for terminal control.

caused the ON.ABORT paragraph to execute. The
values are:
1 An ABORT statement was executed.
2 An abort was requested after pressing the Break
key followed by option A.
3 An internal or fatal error occurred.
4 An AUTO.LOGOUT event occurred.

prompt.

executed.

Number of columns on the terminal.

DATA statement. Values in the dynamic array are

Day of month from @DATE.

Compiler replaces the value with 0.

@FILENAME reflects the current file name being used
in a RetrieVe or UniVerse SQL statement.

Current file name. When used in a virtual field index,
@FILENAME reflects the current file name being used

Specifies the type of operation being performed. Can
be integrated in the indexed subroutine to determine
they type of database operation that caused the
indexed subroutine to fire.
The following values are associated with the
@IDX.IOTYPE:
0 - The value returned when @IDX.IOTYPE is used
outside the context of an indexed subroutine.
1 - The value returned when the SUBR is called
because an INSERT operation is performed.
2 - The value returned when the SUBR is called
because a DELETE operation is performed.
3 - The value returned when the SUBR is called
because an UPDATE operation is used to evaluate the
original value operation.
4 - The value returned when a SUBR i called because
an UPDATE operation is used to evaluate the new
value operation.

Current transaction isolation level for the active
transaction or the current default isolation level if no
transaction exists.
Nesting level of execution statements. Non-stacked.
User login name. Same as @ACCOUNT.

Number of lines on the device to which you are
printing (that is, terminal or printer).

Number of columns on the device to which you are
printing (that is, terminal or printer).
Current month.

Current value counter for columnar listing only. Used
only in I-descriptors. Same as @NV.

break. @NB has a value of 255 on the grand total line.

process.

selected). Used only in I-descriptors. Same as @NI.

Reserved.

Schema name of the current UniVerse account. Non

is not set until the next time they log in to UniVerse.

Number of elements selected from the last select list.
Non-stacked.

Sentence that invoked the current BASIC program.
Any EXECUTE statement updates @SENTENCE.

Transaction level at which the current SQL procedure
began.

Status codes returned by system processes. Same as
@SYSTEM.SET.

Status codes returned by system processes. Same as
@SYSTEM.RETURN.CODE.
Terminal type. Non-stacked.

Inserts a text mark CHAR(251)

a transaction is active; the value 0 indicates that no
transaction exists.

empty string indicates that no transaction exists.

indicates that no transaction exists.

@TTY returns the value 'phantom'. If the process is a
UniVerse API, it returns 'uvcs'.
Note: In PI/Open flavor, @TTY returns an empty string

Name of the current UniVerse account directory. Non

Current year (2 digits).
Current year (4 digits).
Terminates all programs and returns to the UniVerse command level.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the ABORT statement to terminate execution of a BASIC program and return to the UniVerse prompt. ABORT differs from STOP in that a STOP statement returns to the calling environment (for example, a menu, a paragraph, another UniVerse BASIC program following an EXECUTE statement, and so on), whereas ABORT terminates all calling environments as well as the UniVerse BASIC program. You can use it as part of an IF…THEN statement to terminate processing if certain conditions exist.

Keywords.documentation: Terminates all programs and returns to the UniVerse command level. Behaves as if $OPTIONS STOP.MSG were in force.
Terminates all programs and returns to the UniVerse command level. Behaves as if $OPTIONS-STOP.MSG were in force.
The ABS function will return the mathematical absolute of the ()expression.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the ABS function to return the absolute value of any numeric expression. The absolute value of an expression is its unsigned magnitude.

Keywords.documentation: Creates a dynamic array containing the absolute values of a dynamic array.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the ABSS function to return the absolute values of all the elements in a dynamic array. If an element in dynamic.array is the null value, null is returned for that element.

Keywords.documentation:
Accepts an incoming connection attempt on the server side
socket.
Keywords.detail:
acceptConnection(svr_socket, blocking_mode, timeout, in_addr, in_name,
acceptConnection(svr_socket, blocking_mode, timeout, in_addr, in_name,socket_handle)

Keywords.documentation: Calculates the trigonometric arc-cosine of an expression.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the ACOS function to return the trigonometric arc-cosine of expression. expression must be a numeric value. The result is expressed in degrees. If expression evaluates to the null value, null is returned. The ACOS function is the inverse of the COS function.

Keywords.documentation: Activates a key.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the ACTIVATEKEY statement to activate a key. It is necessary to activate a key if you want to supply a password for key protection.

Keywords.documentation:
Adds an authentication rule to a security context. UniVerse uses
the authentication rules during SSL negotiation to determine
whether or not the peer is to be trusted.

Loads a certificate (or multiple certificates) into a security
context to be used as a UniVerse server or client certificate.
Alternatively, it can specify a directory which contains the
certificates that are either used as CA (Certificate Authority)
certificates to authenticate incoming certificates, or act as a
Revocation list to check against expired or revoked certificates.
Keywords.detail: addCertificate(certPath, usedAs, format, algorithm, context, p12pass)

Keywords.documentation: Adds a parameter to the request.
Adds elements of two dynamic arrays.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the ADDS function to create a dynamic array of the element-by-element addition of two dynamic arrays.

Keywords.documentation:
Determines whether the expression is an alphabetic or nonalphabetic
string.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the ALPHA function to determine whether expression is an alphabetic or non-alphabetic string. If expression contains the characters a through z or A through Z, it evaluates to true and a value of 1 is returned. If expression contains any other character or an empty string, it evaluates to false and a value of 0 is returned. If expression evaluates to the null value, null is returned. If NLS is enabled, the ALPHA function uses the characters in the Alphabetics field in the NLS.LC.CTYPE file. For more information, see the Rocket UniVerse NLS User Guide.

Keywords.documentation: Creates and opens an AMI session.
Receives a message sent by the amSendMsg function.
Keywords.detail: amReceiveMsg(hSession, receiverName, policyName, selMsgName, maxMsgLen, dataLen, data, rcvMsgName, reasonCode[,recMsgOption])

Keywords.documentation: Receives a request message.
Keywords.detail: amReceiveRequest(hSession, receiverName, policyName, maxMsgLen, dataLen, data, rcvMsgName, senderName, reasonCode [,recReqOption])

Keywords.documentation: Sends a datagram (send and forget) message
Keywords.detail: amSendMsg(hSession, senderName, policyName, data, sndMsgName, reasonCode)

Keywords.documentation: Sends a request message.
Keywords.detail: amSendRequest(hSession, senderName, policyName, responseName, data, sndMsgName, reasonCode)

Keywords.documentation: Sends a request message.
Keywords.detail: amSendResponse(hSession, senderName, policyName, rcvMsgName, data sndMsgName, reasonCode)

Keywords.documentation: Closes a session.

Decodes a certificate and inputs plain text into the result
parameter. The result parameter then contains such
information as the subject name, location, institute, issuer,
public key, other extensions and the issuers signature.
Performs a logical AND on elements of two dynamic arrays.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the ANDS function to create a dynamic array of the logical AND of corresponding elements of two dynamic arrays.

Keywords.documentation:
Converts EBCDIC representation of character string data to the equivalent ASCII
character code values.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the ASCII function to convert each character of expression from its EBCDIC representation value to its ASCII representation value. If expression evaluates to the null value, null is returned.

Keywords.documentation: Calculates the trigonometric arc-sine of an expression.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the ASIN function to return the trigonometric arc-sine of expression. expression must be a numeric value. The result is expressed in degrees. If expression evaluates to the null value, null is returned. The ASIN function is the inverse of the SIN function.

Keywords.documentation: Determines if a variable is assigned a value.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the ASSIGNED function to determine if variable is assigned a value. ASSIGNED returns 1 (true) if variable is assigned a value, including common variables and the null value. It returns 0 (false) if variable is not assigned a value.

Keywords.documentation: Calculates the trigonometric arctangent of an expression.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the ATAN function to return the trigonometric arc-tangent of expression. expression must be a numeric value. The result is expressed in degrees. If expression evaluates to the null value, null is returned. The ATAN function is the inverse of the TAN function.

Keywords.documentation: Create application driven audit logs.
Keywords.detail: AuditLog(Originator, Action, File, Record, Info, Status, [OldData], [NewData])

Keywords.documentation: Specifies the effective run-time UID (user identification) number of the program.
Assigns the map for the auxiliary printer to print unit 0 (for example, the terminal).
Keywords.snippetDoc: In NLS mode, use the AUXMAP statement to associate an auxiliary device with a terminal.

Keywords.documentation: The CASE structure is bounded by the BEGIN CASE and END CASE statements.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the BEGIN CASE statement to begin a set of CASE statements.

Keywords.documentation: Indicates the beginning of a set of statements that make up a single transaction.
Performs a bitwise AND of two integers.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the BITAND function to perform the bitwise AND comparison of two integers specified by numeric expressions. The bitwise AND operation compares two integers bit by bit. It returns a bit of 1 if both bits are 1; otherwise it returns a bit of 0.

Keywords.documentation: Performs a bitwise NOT of two integers.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the BITNOT function to return the bitwise negation of an integer specified by any numeric expression.

Keywords.documentation: Performs a bitwise OR of two integers.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the BITOR function to perform the bitwise OR comparison of two integers specified by numeric expressions. The bitwise OR operation compares two integers bit by bit. It returns the bit 1 if the bit in either or both numbers is 1; otherwise it returns the bit 0.

Keywords.documentation: Resets one bit of an integer.
Sets one bit of an integer.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the BITSET function to set to 1 the bit number of the integer specified by expression. The number of the rightmost bit is 0. If the bit is 1, it is left unchanged.

Keywords.documentation: Tests one bit of an integer.
Performs a bitwise XOR of two integers.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the BITXOR function to perform the bitwise XOR comparison of two integers specified by numeric expressions. The bitwise XOR operation compares two integers bit by bit. It returns a bit 1 if only one of the two bits is 1; otherwise it returns a bit 0.

Keywords.documentation: Enables or disables the Break key on the keyboard.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the BREAK statement to enable or disable the Intr, Quit, and Susp keys on the keyboard.

Keywords.documentation: Scans the leaf-nodes of a B-tree file (type 25) or a secondary index.
Keywords.detail: BSCAN ID.variable [, rec.variable] [FROM file.variable [, record]] [USING indexname] [RESET] [BY seq] {THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements}
Keywords.snippet:
BSCAN $idVar, $recVar, FROM $filevar, $record USING $indexname RESET BY $seq THEN
	$then_statements
END ELSE
	$else_statements
END
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the BSCAN statement to scan the leaf nodes of a B-tree file (type 25) or of a secondary index. The record ID returned by the current scan operation is assigned to ID.variable. If you specify rec.variable, the contents of the record whose ID is ID.variable is assigned to it.

Keywords.documentation: Generates a string made up of a single byte.
Keywords.snippetDoc: In NLS mode, use the BYTE function to generate a byte from the numeric value of expression. BYTE returns a string containing a single byte.

Keywords.documentation: Generates the number of bytes contained in the string value in an expression.
Keywords.snippetDoc: In NLS mode, use the BYTELEN function to generate the number of bytes contained in the ASCII string value in expression.

Keywords.documentation: Determines the function of a byte in a character.
Keywords.snippetDoc: In NLS mode, use the BYTETYPE function to determine the function of a byte in value.

Keywords.documentation: Retrieves the value of a byte in a string value in an expression.
Keywords.snippetDoc: In NLS mode, use the BYTEVAL function to examine the bytes contained in the internal string value of expression. The BYTEVAL function returns a number from 0 through 255 as the byte value of n in expression. If you omit n, 1 is assumed.

Keywords.documentation: The CALL statement transfers program execution to an external subroutine.
Keywords.detail:
CALL NAME [ ) [MAT] argument [, [MAT] argument ...] ) ]
CALL [@]subroutine.name [(argument [, argument ... ])]
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the CALL statement to transfer program control from the calling program to an external subroutine or program that has been compiled and cataloged.

Keywords.documentation: The CASE statement allows the programmer to execute a particular sequence of instructions based upon the results of a series of test expressions.
Keywords.detail:
BEGIN CASE
CASE expression
statement(s)
CASE expression
statement(s)
.....
END CASE

Keywords.documentation: Concatenates elements of two dynamic arrays.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the CATS function to create a dynamic array of the element-by-element concatenation of two dynamic arrays.

Keywords.documentation: Use the CENTURY.PIVOT function to override the system-wide century pivot year defined in the uvconfig file.
Terminates a BASIC program and executes a UniVerse command.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the CHAIN statement to terminate execution of a UniVerse BASIC program and to execute the value of command. command is an expression that evaluates to any valid UniVerse command. If command evaluates to the null value, the CHAIN statement fails and the program terminates with a runtime error message.

Keywords.documentation: The CHANGE function operates on a variable and replaces all occurrences of one string with another.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the CHANGE function to replace a substring in expression with another substring. If you do not specify occurrence, each occurrence of the substring is replaced.

Keywords.documentation: The CHAR function returns the  ASCII character specified by the expression.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the CHAR function to generate an ASCII character from the numeric value of expression.

Keywords.documentation:
Converts numeric elements of a dynamic array to their ASCII character string
equivalents.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the CHARS function to generate a dynamic array of ASCII characters from the decimal numeric value of each element of dynamic.array.

Keywords.documentation: Returns a cyclical redundancy code (a checksum value).
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the CHECKSUM function to return a cyclical redundancy code (a checksum value).

Keywords.documentation: Assigns a value of 0 to specified variables.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the CLEAR statement at the beginning of a program to set all assigned and unassigned values of variables outside of the common area of the program to 0. This procedure avoids run-time errors for unassigned variables. If you use the CLEAR statement later in the program, any values assigned to noncommon variables (including arrays) are lost.

Keywords.documentation: Set all variables in a named common area to zero.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the UniVerse BASIC CLEARCOMMON command to clear variables in the common area.

Keywords.documentation: Clears all data previously stored by the DATA statement.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the CLEARDATA statement to flush all data that has been loaded in the input stack by the DATA statement. No expressions or spaces are allowed with this statement. Use the CLEARDATA statement when an error is detected, to prevent data placed in the input stack from being used incorrectly.

Keywords.documentation: Erases all records from a file.
Clears the value of the in-line prompt.
Sets a select list to empty.
Writes data written to the file physically on the disk and releases any file or update locks.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the CLOSE statement after opening and processing a file. Any file locks or record locks are released.

Keywords.documentation: Writes an end-of-file mark at the current location in the record and then makes the record available to other users.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the CLOSESEQ statement after opening and processing a file opened for sequential processing. CLOSESEQ makes the file available to other users.

Keywords.documentation: Closes a socket connection.
After you finish using an XML document, use CloseXMLData to close the dynamic array variable.
Returns the column position immediately preceding the selected substring after a BASIC FIELD function is executed.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the COL1 function after the execution of a FIELD function to return the numeric value for the character position that immediately precedes the selected substring. Although the COL1 function takes no arguments, parentheses are required to identify it as a function.

Keywords.documentation: Returns the column position immediately following the selected substring after a BASIC FIELD function is executed.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the COL2 function after the execution of a FIELD function to return the numeric value for the character position that immediately follows the selected substring. Although the COL2 function takes no arguments, parentheses are required to identify it as a function.

Keywords.documentation: Enables or disables the command editor in PI/Open.
Keywords.snippetDoc: The COMMAND.EDITOR command enables or disables the Command Editor in PI/open. The Command Editor provides you with facilities for simple command line editing and command stack manipulation.

Keywords.documentation: Commits all changes made during a transaction, writing them to disk.
The COMMON statement declares a list of variables and matrices that can be shared among various programs. There can be many common areas including a default, unnamed common area.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the COMMON statement to provide a storage area for variables. Variables in the common area are accessible to main programs and external subroutines. Corresponding variables can have different names in the main program and in external subroutines, but they must be defined in the same order. The COMMON statement must precede any reference to the variables it names.

Keywords.documentation: Compares two strings for sorting.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the COMPARE function to compare two strings and return a numeric value indicating the result.

Keywords.documentation: The CONTINUE statement is the complimentary statement to the BREAK statement without arguments. The statement is used within a loop to skip the remaining code in the current iteration and proceed directly to the next iteration.
The CONVERT statement converts one or more characters (searchString) in a string to their corresponding replacementString characters.
Keywords.detail: CONVERT searchString TO replacementString IN string

Keywords.documentation: Replaces every occurrence of specified characters in a variable with other specified characters.
Calculates the trigonometric cosine of an angle.
Calculates the hyperbolic cosine of an expression.
Evaluates the number of times a substring is repeated in a string.
Evaluates the number of times a substring is repeated in each element of a dynamic array.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the COUNTS function to count the number of times a substring is repeated in each element of a dynamic array. The result is a new dynamic array whose elements are the counts corresponding to the elements in dynamic.array.

Keywords.documentation: Creates a record in a UniVerse type 1 or type 19 file or establishes a path.
Keywords.detail: CREATE file.variable {THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements}
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the CREATE statement after an OPENSEQ statement to create a record in a type 1 or type 19 UniVerse file or to create a UNIX or DOS file. CREATE creates the record or file if the OPENSEQ statement fails. An OPENSEQ statement for the specified file.variable must be executed before the CREATE statement to associate the path or record ID of the file to be created with the file.variable. If file.variable is the null value, the CREATE statement fails and the program terminates with a runtime error message.

Keywords.documentation:
Generates a certificate. The certificate can either be a self
signed certificate as a root CA that can then be used later to
sign other certificates, or it can be a CA signed certificate. The
generated certificate conforms to X509V3 standard.
Keywords.detail: createCertificate(action, req, signKey, keyPass, CAcert, days, extensions, certOut, signAlg)

Keywords.documentation:
Generates a PKCS #10 certificate request from a private
key in PKCS #8 form and a set of user specified data. The
request can be sent to a CA or used as a parameter to the
createCertificate() function to obtain an X.509 public key
certificate.
Keywords.detail: createCertRequest(key, inFormat, keyLoc, algorithm, digest, passPhrase,subjectData, outFile, outFormat)

Keywords.documentation: Creates an HTTP request and returns a handle to the request.
Creates a security context and returns a handle to the context.
The CRT statement sends data directly to the terminal, even if a PRINTER ON statement is currently active. If the optional ':' is appended, no carriage return is appended to the text
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the CRT statement to print data on the screen, regardless of whether a PRINTER ON statement has been executed. The syntax for print.list is the same as for a PRINT statement.

Keywords.documentation: Stores values to be used in subsequent requests for data input.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the DATA statement to place values in an input stack. These values can be used as responses to INPUT statements executed later in the program or in a subroutine. The values can also serve as responses to UniVerse commands that request input.

Keywords.documentation: The DATE( ) function returns the date in internal system form. This date is expressed as the number of days since (or before) December 31, 1967.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the DATE function to return the numeric value of the internal system date. Although the DATE function takes no arguments, parentheses are required to identify it as a function.

Keywords.documentation: Create an XML document from UniVerse data using UniVerse BASIC.
Keywords.snippetDoc: To create an XML document from the UniVerse database using UniVerse BASIC, use the DBTOXML function.

Keywords.documentation: The DCOUNT() function counts the number of field elements in a string that are separated by a specified delimiter.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the DCOUNT function to return the number of delimited fields in a data string.

Keywords.documentation: Deactivate one or mor encryption keys.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the DEACTIVATEKEY command to deactivate one or more encryption keys. This command is useful to deactivate keys to make your system more secure.

Keywords.documentation: The DEBUG statement causes the executing program to enter the UniVerse debugger.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the DEBUG statement to invoke RAID, the interactive UniVerse BASIC debugger. The DEBUG statement takes no arguments. When this statement is encountered, program execution stops and the double colon (:: ) prompt appears, waiting for a RAID command. The following table summarizes the RAID commands.

Keywords.documentation: Defines a user-written function.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the DEFFUN statement to define a user-written function. You must declare a user-defined function before you can use it in a program. The DEFFUN statement provides the compiler with information such as the function name and the number and type of arguments. You can define a user-written function only once in a program. A subsequent DEFFUN statement for an already defined user-written function causes a fatal error.

Keywords.documentation: Deletes the specified field, value, or subvalue from a dynamic array.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the DEL statement to delete a field, value, or subvalue from a dynamic array. The DEL statement works similarly to the DELETE function.

Keywords.documentation: The DEL or DELETE statement is used to remove a specified element from a dynamic array.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the DELETE statements to delete a record from a UniVerse file. If you specify a file variable, the file must be open when the DELETE statement is encountered.

Keywords.documentation: The DELETE statement is used to delete a record from a UniVerse file.
Deletes a select list saved in the &SAVEDLISTS& file.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the DELETELIST statement to delete a select list saved in the &SAVEDLISTS& file.

Keywords.documentation: Deletes a record from a previously opened file without releasing the update lock.
Keywords.detail:
DELETEU [file.variable ,] record.ID [ON ERROR statements]
[LOCKED statements]
[THEN statements] [ELSE statements]

Keywords.documentation: Returns requested information (key) about a variable.
Keywords.snippetDoc: The DESCRINFO function returns requested information (key) about a variable. Set the key value to 1 to obtain information about the type of variable. Set the key value to 2 to obtain the reuse flag of the variable. Any other value is invalid, and will result in the program exiting.

Keywords.documentation: Generates a message digest of supplied data. A message digest is the result of a one-way hash function (digest algorithm) performed on the message.
Keywords.snippetDoc: The DIGEST() function generates a message digest of supplied data. A message digest is the result of a one-way hash function (digest algorithm) performed on the message. Message digest has the unique properties that a slight change in the input will result in a significant difference in the resulting digest. Therefore, the probability of two different messages resulting in the same digest (collision) is very unlikely. It is also virtually impossible to reverse to the original message from a digest. Message digest is widely used for digital signatures and other purposes.

Keywords.documentation: The DIM statement is used to declare arrays to the compiler before they are referenced.
Declares the name, dimensionality, and size constraints of an array variable.
Keywords.detail:
DIM[ENSION] matrix (rows, columns) [, matrix (rows, columns) ]
DIM[ENSION] vector (subscript) [, vector (subscript) ]
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the DIMENSION statement to define the dimensions of an array variable before referencing the array in the program. For a matrix (a two-dimensional array), use the DIMENSION statement to set the maximum number of rows and columns available for the elements of the array. For a vector (a one-dimensional array), use the DIMENSION statement to set the maximum value of the subscript (the maximum elements) in the array.

Keywords.documentation: Turn off decryption on field or fields specified.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the DISABLEDEC command to turn off decryption on a field or fields you specify.

Keywords.documentation: Outputs data to the screen.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the DISPLAY statement to print data on the screen, regardless of whether a PRINTER ON statement has been executed. The syntax for print.list is the same as for PRINT statement.

Keywords.documentation: Outputs the whole part of the real division of two real numbers.
Divides elements of two dynamic arrays.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Each element of array1 is divided by the corresponding element of array2 with the result being returned in the corresponding element of a new dynamic array. If elements of array1 have no corresponding elements in array2, array2 is padded with ones and the array1 elements are returned. If an element of array2 has no corresponding element in array1, 0 is returned. If an element of array2 is 0, a run-time error message is printed and a 0 is returned. If either element of a corresponding pair is the null value, null is returned.

Keywords.documentation: DOWNCASE converts all uppercase characters in an expression to lowercase characters.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the DOWNCASE function to change all uppercase letters in expression to lowercase. If expression evaluates to the null value, null is returned.

Keywords.documentation: The function will put double quotation mark at the beginning and end of a string
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the DQUOTE function to enclose an expression in double quotation marks. If expression evaluates to the null value, null is returned (without quotation marks).

Keywords.documentation: Converts a decimal integer into its hexadecimal equivalent.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the DTX function to convert a decimal integer to its hexadecimal equivalent. size indicates the minimum size which the hexadecimal character string should have. This field is supplemented with zeros if appropriate. If number evaluates to the null value, null is returned. If size is the null value, the DTX function fails and the program terminates with a runtime error message.

Keywords.documentation:
Converts data from its ASCII representation to the equivalent code value in
EBCDIC.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the EBCDIC function to convert each character of expression from its ASCII representation value to its EBCDIC representation value. The EBCDIC and ASCII functions perform complementary operations. Data that is not represented in ASCII code produces undefined results.

Keywords.documentation: Controls the display of input characters on the terminal screen.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the ECHO statement to control the display of input characters on the screen.

Keywords.documentation: Activate decryption on a file or fields specified.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the ENABLEDEC command to activate decryption on a file or fields you specify.

Keywords.documentation:
Performs data encoding on input data. UniVerse supports
Base64 encoding only.
Keywords.detail: ENCODE(algorithm, action, data, dataLoc, result, resultLoc)
Keywords.snippetDoc: The ENCODE() function performs data encoding on input data. The function can perform either encoding or decoding, as specified by action. The data can either be in the dynamic array, data, or in a file whose name is specified in data, determined by dataLoc.

Keywords.documentation: Performs symmetric encryption operations. You can call various block and stream symmetric ciphers through this function.
Keywords.detail: ENCRYPT (algorithm, action, data, dataLoc,key, keyLoc, keyAction, salt, IV, result, resultLoc, signAlg)
Keywords.snippet: ENCRYPT (algorithm, action, data, dataLoc,key, keyLoc, keyAction, salt, $IV, $result, $resultLoc)
Keywords.snippetDoc: The ENCRYPT() function performs symmetric encryption operations. Various block and stream symmetric ciphers can be called through this function.

Keywords.documentation: The END statement is used to terminate a program or to conclude a set of jBC statements bounded by a condition.
The END CASE statement terminates a CASE block. There should be a corresponding END CASE for each BEGIN CASE.
The END ELSE terminates the THEN portion and begin the ELSE portion of a code block
Indicates where execution should continue after a transaction terminates.
Executes an external subroutine.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the ENTER statement to transfer program control from the calling program to an external subroutine without returning to the calling program. The subroutine must have been compiled and cataloged.

Keywords.documentation: Checks whether the command line argument pointer is past the last command line argument.
Compares the equality of corresponding elements of two dynamic arrays.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the EQS function to test if elements of one dynamic array are equal to the elements of another dynamic array.

Keywords.documentation: EQUATE is used to declare a symbol equivalent to a literal, variable or simple expression.
Keywords.detail:
EQU[ATE] symbol TO expression [,symbol TO expression ]
EQU[ATE] symbol LIT[ERALLY] string [,symbol LIT string ]
Keywords.snippetDoc: In an EQUATE statement, symbol represents the value of expression or string. You can use the two interchangeably in the program. When the program is compiled, each occurrence of symbol is replaced by the value of expression or string. The value is compiled as object code and does not have to be reassigned each time the program is executed.

Keywords.documentation: Substitutes an element of a string with a replacement element.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the EREPLACE function to replace substring in expression with another substring. If you do not specify occurrence, each occurrence of substring is replaced.

Keywords.documentation: Prints a formatted error message from the ERRMSG file.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the ERRMSG statement to print a formatted error message from the ERRMSG file. message.ID is an expression evaluating to the record ID of a message to be printed on the screen. Additional expressions are evaluated as arguments that can be included in the error message.

Keywords.documentation: Replaces one character with another or deletes all occurrences of a specific character.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the EXCHANGE function to replace one character with another or to delete all occurrences of the specified character.

Keywords.documentation: The EXECUTE or PERFORM statement allows the currently executing program to pause and execute any other UNIX/NT program, including another jBC program or a jBASE command.
Keywords.detail:
EXECUTE|PERFORM expression [CAPTURING variable] [RETURNING|SETTING variable]
[PASSLIST expression] [RTNLIST [variable]]
[PASSDATA variable] [RTNDATA variable]
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the EXECUTE statement to execute UniVerse commands from within the BASIC program and then return execution to the statement following the EXECUTE statement.

Keywords.documentation: The EXIT statement is used to halt the execution of a program and return a numeric exit code to the parent process. For compatibility with older versions of the language the EXIT statement may be used without an expression. In this case it is synonymous with the BREAK statement.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the EXIT statement to quit execution of a FOR...NEXT loop or a LOOP...REPEAT loop and branch to the statement following the NEXT or REPEAT statement of the loop. The EXIT statement quits exactly one loop. When loops are nested and the EXIT statement is executed in an inner loop, the outer loop remains in control.

Keywords.documentation: Calculates the result of base "e" raised to the power designated by the value of the expression.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the EXP function to return the value of "e" raised to the power designated by expression. The value of "e" is approximately 2.71828. expression must evaluate to a numeric value.

Keywords.documentation: Extracts the contents of a specified field, value, or subvalue from a dynamic array.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the EXTRACT function to access the data contents of a specified field, value, or subvalue from a dynamic array. You can use either syntax shown to extract data. The first syntax uses the EXTRACT keyword, the second uses angle brackets.

Keywords.documentation: Performs floating-point addition on two numeric values. This function is provided for compatibility with existing software.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the FADD function to perform floating-point addition on two numeric values. If either number evaluates to the null value, null is returned. If either number1 or number2 evaluates to the null value, null is returned. return.array equates to number1 plus number2. This function is provided for compatibility with existing software. You can also use the + operator to perform floating-point addition.

Keywords.documentation: Performs floating-point division on two numeric values.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the FDIV function to perform floating-point division on two numeric values. number1 is divided by number2. return.array equates to number1 divided by number2. If number2 is 0, a runtime error message is produced and a 0 is returned for the function. If either number evaluates to the null value, null is returned.

Keywords.documentation:
Converts a floating-point number to a string with a fixed precision. FFIX is
provided for compatibility with existing software.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the FFIX function to convert a floating-point number to a numeric string with fixed precision. If number evaluates to the null value, null is returned.

Keywords.documentation: Rounds a number to a string with a precision of 14.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the FFLT function to round a number to a string with a precision of 13. The number also converts to scientific notation when required for precision. If number evaluates to the null value, null is returned.

Keywords.documentation: The FIELD function will return a multi-character delimited field from within a string.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the FIELD function to return one or more substrings located between specified delimiters in string.

Keywords.documentation: Examines each element of a dynamic array for any occurrence of a specified delimiter and returns substrings that are marked by that delimiter.
Replaces, deletes, or inserts substrings in a specified character string.
Returns information about the specified files configuration.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the FILEINFO function to return information about the specified file’s configuration, such as the specified file’s parameters, its modulus and load, its operating system file name, and its VOC name. The information returned depends on the file type and the value of the key.

Keywords.documentation:
Sets a file update lock on an entire file to prevent other users from updating the
file until this program releases it.
Releases file locks set by the FILELOCK statement.
Locates a given occurrence of an element within a dynamic array.
Keywords.detail: FIND element IN dynamic.array [,occurrence] SETTING fmc [,vmc [,smc]] {THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements}

Keywords.documentation: Locates a given occurrence of a substring.
Keywords.detail: FINDSTR substring IN dynamic.array [,occurrence] SETTING fmc [,vmc [,smc]] {THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements}
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the FINDSTR statement to locate substring in dynamic.array. The field, value, and subvalue positions of substring are placed in the variables fmc, vmc, and smc respectively.

Keywords.documentation: Rounds an expression to a decimal number having the accuracy specified by the PRECISION statement.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the FIX function to convert a numeric value to a floating-point number with a specified precision. FIX lets you control the accuracy of computation by eliminating excess or unreliable data from numeric results. For example, a bank application that computes the interest accrual for customer accounts does not need to deal with credits expressed in fractions of cents. An engineering application needs to throw away digits that are beyond the accepted reliability of computations.

Keywords.documentation: Causes all buffers to be written simultaneously.
Keywords.detail: FLUSH file.variable {THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements }
Keywords.snippetDoc: The FLUSH statement causes all the buffers for a sequential I/O file to be written immediately. Normally, sequential I/O uses UNIX "stdio" buffering for input/output operations, and writes are not performed immediately.

Keywords.documentation: Converts data from its internal representation to a specified format for output.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the FMT function or a format expression to format data for output. Any BASIC expression can be formatted for output by following it with a format expression.

Keywords.documentation: Formats data for output in display positions rather than character lengths.
Keywords.snippetDoc: In NLS mode, use the FMTDP function to format data for output in display positions rather than character lengths.

Keywords.documentation: Converts elements of a dynamic array from their internal representation to a specified format for output.
Formats elements of a dynamic array for output in display positions rather than character lengths.
Keywords.snippetDoc: In NLS mode, use the FMTSDP function to format elements of dynamic.array for output in display positions rather than character lengths. Each element of the array is acted upon independently and is returned as an element in a new dynamic array. Any unmappable characters in dynamic.array are assumed to have a display length of 1.

Keywords.documentation: Performs floating-point multiplication on two numeric values. This function is provided for compatibility with existing software.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the FMUL function to perform floating-point multiplication on two numeric values. If either number evaluates to the null value, null is returned. return.array equates to number1 multiplied by number2.

Keywords.documentation: Divides a string into a number of shorter sections.
Divides a string into a number of substrings separated by field marks, in display positions rather than character lengths.
Specifies text to be printed at the bottom of each page.

The FOR statement allows the programming of looping constructs within the program. The loop is controlled by a counting variable and may be terminated early by expressions tested after every iteration.
Keywords.detail:
FOR var = expression1 TO expression2 [STEP expression3]

[WHILE | UNTIL expression4]
NEXT [var]

Keywords.documentation: The FORMLIST statement creates an active select list from a dynamic array.
Keywords.snippetDoc: The FORMLIST statement is the same as the SELECT statements.

Keywords.documentation: Performs floating-point subtraction on two numeric values.
Identifies a user-written function.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the FUNCTION statement to identify a user-written function and to specify the number and names of the arguments to be passed to it. The FUNCTION statement must be the first noncomment line in the user-written function. A user-written function can contain only one FUNCTION statement.

Keywords.documentation:
Generates a public key cryptography key pair and encrypts the
private key.
Keywords.detail: generateKey(privKey, pubKey, format, keyLoc, algorithm, keyLength,passPhrase, paramFile)

Keywords.documentation: Indicates when elements of one dynamic array are greater than or equal to corresponding elements of another dynamic array.
Reads a block of data from an input stream associated with a device, such as a serial line or terminal.
Keywords.detail: GET[X] read.var[, length] [SETTING read.count] FROM device [UNTIL eop.char.list ] [RETURNING last.char.read ] [WAITING seconds ] [THEN statements ] [ELSE statements]

Keywords.documentation: Retrieves a command line argument.

Obtains information about supported cipher suites, their
version, usage, strength and type for the specified security
context.
Returns the default values of the HTTP settings.
Display the current IPv setting on the system or a particular network connection.
Activates a saved select list so it can be used by a READNEXT statement.
Keywords.detail: GETLIST listname [TO list.number] [SETTING variable] {THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements}

Keywords.documentation: Retrieves the names of specified categories of the current locale.
Returns the numeric value for the position of the REMOVE pointer associated with a dynamic array.
Translates an error code into a text error message.
Obtains information about a socket connection.
Gets the NLS map associated with the input socket handle.

Gets the current value for a socket option associated with a
socket of any type.
Reads a block of data from an input stream associated with a device, and returns the characters in ASCII hexadecimal format.
The GOSUB statement causes execution of a local subroutine, after which execution will continue with the next line of code.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the GOSUB statement to transfer program control to an internal subroutine referenced by statement.label. A colon (: ) is optional in GOSUB statements, even though it is required after nonnumeric statement labels at the beginning of program lines.

Keywords.documentation: The GOTO statement causes program execution to jump to the code at a specified label.
Keywords.detail:
GOTO label[:]
GO TO label[:]
GO label[:]

Keywords.documentation: Returns a substring that is located between the stated number of occurrences of a delimiter.
Modifies existing character strings by inserting, deleting, or replacing substrings that are separated by a delimiter character.
Keywords.detail: GROUPSTORE new.string IN string USING start, n [ ,delimiter]

Keywords.documentation: Indicates when elements of one dynamic array are greater than corresponding elements of another dynamic array.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the GTS function to test if elements of one dynamic array are greater than elements of another dynamic array.

Keywords.documentation: Specifies text to be printed at the top of each page.
Specifies text to be printed at the top of each page with the $OPTIONS statement HEADER.EJECT selected.
Specifies text to be printed at the top of each page with the $OPTIONS statement -HEADER.EJECT selected.
Calculate a message authentication code (MAC) involving a cryptographic hash function in combination with a secret key.
Suppresses all text normally sent to a terminal during processing.
Verifies that specified data and primary keys satisfy the defined SQL integrity constraints for an SQL table.
The ICONV function converts data in external form such as dates to their internal form.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the ICONV function to convert string to a specified internal storage format. string is an expression that evaluates to the string to be converted.

Keywords.documentation: Converts elements of a dynamic array to internal storage format.
Determines program flow based on the evaluation of an expression.
Keywords.detail: IF expression {THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements}

Keywords.documentation: Evaluates a dynamic array and creates another dynamic array on the basis of the truth or falsity of its elements.
Evaluates strings containing in-line prompts.
Inserts and includes the specified BASIC source code from another program into the program being compiled. Same as the #INCLUDE and $INCLUDE statements.
Keywords.detail:
INCLUDE [filename] program
INCLUDE program FROM filename
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the INCLUDE statement to direct the compiler to insert the source code in the record program and compile it along with the main program. The INCLUDE statement differs from the $CHAIN statement in that the compiler returns to the main program and continues compiling with the statement following the INCLUDE statement.

Keywords.documentation: The INDEX function will return the position of a character or characters within another string.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the INDEX function to return the starting character position for the specified occurrence of substring in string.

Keywords.documentation: Returns the starting column position of a specified occurrence of a particular substring within each element of a dynamic array.
Returns information about the secondary key indexes in a file.
Creates a secured connection-oriented stream server socket.
Creates a connection-oriented (stream) socket.
Used with the MATPARSE, MATREAD, and MATREADU statements to return the number of array elements or with the OPEN statement to return the modulo of a file.
Allows data input from the keyboard during program execution.

Positions the cursor at a specified location and defines the length of the
input field.
Clears the type-ahead buffer.
Positions the cursor at a specified location and defines a format for the variable to print.

In NLS mode, use the INPUTDP statement to let the user enter data. The INPUTDP statement is similar to the INPUT, INPUTIF, and INPUTDISP statements, but it calculates display positions rather than character lengths.
Prints a formatted error message from the ERRMSG file on the bottom line of the terminal.
Assigns the contents of the type-ahead buffer to a variable.
Defines a single character to be recognized as the empty string in an INPUT @ statement.
Branches to a program label or subroutine on a TRAP key.
Inserts a specified field, value, or subvalue into a dynamic array.
Inserts a field, value, or subvalue into a dynamic array.
Keywords.detail:
INSERT (dynamic.array, field#, value#, subvalue#, expression)
INSERT (dynamic.array, field# [ ,value# [,subvalue#]] ; expression)

Keywords.documentation: The INT function truncates a numeric value into its nearest integer form.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the INT function to return the integer portion of an expression.

Keywords.documentation: Indicates when a variable is the null value.
Indicates when an element of a dynamic array is the null value.
Returns the value resulting from the evaluation of an I-descriptor.
Assigns specific editing functions to the keys on the keyboard to be used with the INPUT statement.
Specifies exit traps for the keys assigned editing functions by the KEYEDIT statement.
Reads a single character from the input buffer and returns it.
Specifies traps for the keys assigned specific functions by the KEYEDIT statement.
Specifies a substring consisting of the first n characters of a string.
The LEN function returns the character length of the supplied expression.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the LEN function to return the number of characters in string. Calculations are based on character length rather than display length.

Keywords.documentation: Returns the number of display positions in a string.
Calculates the length of each element of a dynamic array.
Returns a dynamic array of the number of display positions in each element of a dynamic array.
Indicates when elements of one dynamic array are less than or equal to corresponding elements of another dynamic array.
Assigns a value to a variable.
Calculates the natural logarithm of an expression in base "e".
Loads a saved security context record into the current session.
Retrieves the settings of the current locale.
Searches a dynamic array for a particular value or string, and returns the index of its position.
Keywords.detail: LOCATE expression IN dynamic.array [< field# [, value#] >] [, start] [BY seq] SETTING variable {THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements}

Keywords.documentation: Sets an execution lock to protect user-defined resources or events from being used by more than one concurrently running program.
The LOOP construct allows the programmer to specify loops with multiple exit conditions.
Keywords.detail: LOOP statements1 WHILE|UNTIL expression DO statements2 REPEAT

Keywords.documentation: The LOWER function lowers system delimiters in a string to the next lowest delimiter.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the LOWER function to return a value equal to expression, except that system delimiters which appear in expression are converted to the next lower-level delimiter: field marks are changed to value marks, value marks are changed to subvalue marks, and so on. If expression evaluates to the null value, null is returned.

Keywords.documentation:
Indicates when elements of one dynamic array are less than corresponding
elements of another dynamic array.
The MAT command is used to either assign every element in a specified array to a single value or to assign the entire contents of one array to another.
Keywords.detail:
MAT Array = expression
MAT Array1 = MAT Array2
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the MAT statement to assign one value to all of the elements in the array or to assign all the values of one array to the values of another array.

Keywords.documentation: Builds a string by concatenating the elements of an array.
The MATCH or MATCHES function allows pattern matching to be applied to an expression.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the MATCH operator or its synonym MATCHES to compare a string expression with a pattern.

Keywords.documentation:
Returns the contents of a substring that matches a specified pattern or
part of a pattern.
Assigns the elements of an array from the elements of a dynamic array.
Keywords.detail:
MATPARSE array FROM dynamic.array [,delimiter]
MATPARSE array [,start [,end]] FROM dynamic.array [USING delimiter] [SETTING elements]

Keywords.documentation: Assigns the data stored in successive fields of a record from a UniVerse file to the consecutive elements of an array.
Keywords.detail: MATREAD array FROM [file.variable,] record.ID [ON ERROR statements]

Keywords.documentation: Sets a shared read lock on a record, then assigns the data stored in successive fields of the record to the consecutive elements of an array.
Keywords.detail: MATREADL array FROM [file.variable,] record.ID [ON ERROR statements] [LOCKED statements] {THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements}

Keywords.documentation: Sets an exclusive update lock on a record, then assigns the data stored in successive fields of the record to the consecutive elements of an array
Keywords.detail: MATREADU array FROM [file.variable,] record.ID [ON ERROR statements] [LOCKED statements] {THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements}

Keywords.documentation: Assigns the data stored in consecutive elements of an array to the successive fields of a record in a UniVerse file.
Keywords.detail: MATWRITE array ON | TO [file.variable,] record.ID [ON ERROR statements] [LOCKED statements] [THEN statements] [ELSE statements]

Keywords.documentation: Assigns the data stored in consecutive elements of an array to the successive fields of a record in a UniVerse file, retaining any update locks set on the record.
Keywords.detail: MATWRITEU array ON | TO [file.variable,] record.ID [ON ERROR statements] [LOCKED statements] [THEN statements] [ELSE statements]

Keywords.documentation: Returns the element with the highest numeric value in a dynamic array.
Returns the element with the lowest numeric value in a dynamic array.
Calculates the modulo (the remainder) of two expressions.
Calculates the modulo (the remainder) of elements of two dynamic arrays.
Close access to a queue or other object.
Connects an application to a WebSphere MQ queue manager.
Terminates connections to the queue manager.
Multiplies elements of two dynamic arrays.
Suspends execution of a BASIC program, pausing for a specified number of milliseconds.
Returns the arithmetic additive inverse of the value of the argument.
Returns the negative numeric values of elements in a dynamic array. If the value of an element is negative, the returned value is positive.
Indicates when elements of one dynamic array are not equal to corresponding elements of another dynamic array.
The NEXT statement terminates a FOR loop. Control is passed back to the FOR statement and the variable is incremented or decremented.
Turns off buffering for a sequential file.
Keywords.detail: NOBUF file.variable {THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements }

Keywords.documentation: The NOT function is used to invert the Boolean value of an expression. It useful for explicitly testing for a false condition.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the NOT function to return the logical complement of the value of expression. If the value of expression is true, the NOT function returns a value of false (0). If the value of expression is false, the NOT function returns a value of true (1).

Keywords.documentation: Returns the complement of the logical value of each element of a dynamic array.
Indicates that no operation is to be performed.
Returns true (1) if the argument is a numeric data type; otherwise, returns false (0).

Returns true (1) for each element of a dynamic array that is a numeric data type;
otherwise, returns false (0).
The OCONV statement is used to convert internal representations of data to their external form.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the OCONV function to convert string to a specified format for external output. The result is always a string expression.

Keywords.documentation: Converts elements of a dynamic array from their internal representation to an external output format.

Transfers program control to a specified internal subroutine or to a specified
statement, under specified conditions.

The OPEN statement is used to open a file or device to a descriptor variable.
If the OPEN statement fails, it executes any statements associated with an ELSE clause. If the OPEN is successful it will execute any statements associated with a THEN clause. Note that either one or both of the THEN and ELSE clauses are required.
Keywords.detail: OPEN [dict,] filename [TO file.variable] [ON ERROR statements] {THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements}
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the OPEN statement to open a UniVerse file for use by BASIC programs. All file references in a BASIC program must be preceded by either an OPEN statement or an OPENCHECK statement for that file. You can open several UniVerse files at the same point in a program, but you must use a separate OPEN statement for each file.

Keywords.documentation:
Opens an SQL table for use by BASIC programs, enforcing SQL integrity
checking.
Keywords.detail: OPENCHECK [dict,] filename [TO file.variable] {THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements}

Keywords.documentation: Opens a device for input or output.
Keywords.detail: OPENDEV device TO file.variable [LOCKED statements] {THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements}

Keywords.documentation: Opens a file to be used in a BASIC program.
Keywords.detail:
OPENPATH pathname [TO file.variable] [ON ERROR statements] {THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements}
statement

Keywords.documentation:
Opens a secure socket connection in a specified mode and
return the status.
Keywords.detail: openSecureSocket(name_or_IP, port, mode, timeout, socket_handle, context)

Keywords.documentation: Prepares a UniVerse file for sequential use by the BASIC program.
Keywords.detail:
OPENSEQ filename, record.ID TO file.variable [USING dynamic.array] [ON ERROR statements] [LOCKED statements] {THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements}
OPENSEQ pathname TO file.variable [USING dynamic.array] [ON ERROR statements] [LOCKED statements] {THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements}

Keywords.documentation:
Opens a socket connection in a specified mode and returns the
status.
Opens an XML document after it is prepared.
Performs a logical OR on elements of two dynamic arrays.

Prints a footing at the bottom of the page, advances to the next page, and
prints a heading at the top.

Executes a specified UniVerse sentence, paragraph, menu, or command from
within the BASIC program, and then returns execution to the statement following
the PERFORM statement.

Sets the maximum number of decimal places allowed in the conversion from the
internal binary format of a numeric value to the string representation.

Allocates memory for the XML document, opens the document,
determines the file structure of the document, and returns the file structure.
The PRINT statement sends data directly to the current output device, which will either be the terminal or the printer.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the PRINT statement to send data to the screen, a line printer, or another print file.

Keywords.documentation: Print all output data stored in the printer buffer.
PRINTER OFF will cause all subsequent output from the PRINT statement to be redirected to the terminal device.
PRINTER ON will cause all subsequent output from the PRINT statement to be redirected to the print spooler.
Resets the printing options.

Prints a formatted error message from the ERRMSG file on the bottom line
of the terminal.
Assigns the contents of the primary input buffer of the proc to a variable.
Keywords.detail: PROCREAD variable {THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements}

Keywords.documentation: Writes the specified string to the primary input buffer of the proc that called your BASIC program.
Performs no function other than to document the source code.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the PROGRAM statement to identify a program. The PROGRAM statement is optional; if you use it, it must be the first noncomment line in the program.

Keywords.documentation: Defines the prompt character for user input.
Starts or stops logging.
Calculates the value of an expression when raised to a specified power.
Calls a Python callable object.
The PyCallFunction function calls a Python function on a Python module.
The PyCallMethod function calls a method on a Python object.
The PyGetAttr function gets the value of an attribute of a Python object.
The PyImport function imports a Python module
The PySetAttr function sets the value of an attribute of a Python object.
Encloses an expression in double quotation marks.
The RAISE function raises system delimiters in a string to the next highest delimiter.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the RAISE function to return a value equal to expression, except that system delimiters in expression are converted to the next higher-level delimiter: value marks are changed to field marks, subvalue marks are changed to value marks, and so on. If expression evaluates to the null value, null is returned.

Keywords.documentation: Initializes the RND function to ensure that the same sequence of random numbers is generated after initialization.
The READ statement allows a program to read a record from a previously opened file into a variable.
Keywords.detail: READ dynamic.array FROM [file.variable,] record.ID [ON ERROR statements] READ dynamic.array FROM [file.variable,] record.ID [ON ERROR statements]
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use READ statements to assign the contents of a record from a UniVerse file to dynamic.array.

Keywords.documentation: Reads a block of data from a UniVerse file open for sequential processing and assigns it to a variable.
Keywords.detail: READBLK variable FROM file.variable, blocksize THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements }

Keywords.documentation: Sets a shared read lock on a record, then assigns the contents of the record to a dynamic array variable.
Keywords.detail: READL dynamic.array FROM [file.variable ,] record.ID [ON ERROR statements] [LOCKED statements] { THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements }

Keywords.documentation: READLIST allows the program to retrieve a previously stored list (perhaps created with the SAVE-LIST command), into a variable
Keywords.detail: READLIST dynamic.array [FROM list.number] { THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements }
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the READLIST statement to read the remainder of an active select list into a dynamic array.

Keywords.documentation: READNEXT retrieves the next element in a list variable.
Keywords.detail: READNEXT dynamic.array [,value [,subvalue]] [FROM list] {THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements}

Keywords.documentation: Reads a line of data from a UniVerse file opened for sequential processing and assigns it to a variable.
Keywords.detail: READSEQ variable FROM file.variable [ON ERROR statements] {THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements}

Keywords.documentation:
Reads data in the socket buffer up to max_read_size
characters.
Keywords.detail: readSocket(socket_handle, socket_data, max_read_size, time_out, mode, actual_read_size)

Keywords.documentation:
Assigns the contents of the next record from a magnetic tape unit to the
named variable.
Keywords.detail: READT [UNIT (mtu)] variable {THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements}

Keywords.documentation: The READU statement allows a program to read a record from a previously opened file into a variable. It respects record locking and locks the specified record for update.
Keywords.detail: READU dynamic.array FROM [file.variable ,] record.ID [ON ERROR statements] [LOCKED statements] { THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements }
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the READU statement to set an update record lock and perform the READ statement.

Keywords.documentation: The READV statement allows a program to read a specific field from a record in a previously opened file into a variable.
Keywords.detail: READV dynamic.array FROM [file.variable ,] record.ID , field# [ON ERROR statements] { THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements }
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the READV statement to read the contents of a specified field of a record in a UniVerse file.

Keywords.documentation:
Sets a shared read lock on a record, then assigns the contents of a field of a
record to a dynamic array variable.
Keywords.detail: READVL dynamic.array FROM [file.variable ,] record.ID , field# [ON ERROR statements] [LOCKED statements] { THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements }

Keywords.documentation:
Sets an exclusive update lock on a record, then assigns the contents of a field of
the record to a dynamic array variable.
Keywords.detail: READVU dynamic.array FROM [file.variable ,] record.ID , field# [ON ERROR statements] [LOCKED statements] { THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements }

Keywords.documentation: Reads an XML document after it is opened. UniVerse BASIC returns the XML data as a dynamic array.
Converts a numeric expression into a real number without loss of accuracy.
Establishes whether or not a record is locked by a user.
Sets a shared read-only lock on a record in a file.
Keywords.detail: RECORDLOCKL file.variable , record.ID [ON ERROR statements] [LOCKED statements]

Keywords.documentation: Locks the specified record to prevent other users from accessing it.
Keywords.detail: RECORDLOCKU file.variable , record.ID [ON ERROR statements] [LOCKED statements]

Keywords.documentation: The RELEASE statement explicitly releases record locks without updating the records using a WRITE or DELETE and it also clears all execution locks without issuing an UNLOCK.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the RELEASE statement to unlock, or release, locks set by a FILELOCK statement, MATREADL statement, MATREADU statement, READL statement, READU statement, READVL statement, READVU statement, and OPENSEQ statement. These statements lock designated records to prevent concurrent updating by other users. If you do not explicitly release a lock that you have set, it is unlocked automatically when the program terminates.

Keywords.documentation: Releases the XML dynamic array after closing. ReleaseXML destroys the internal DOM tree and releases the associated memory.
Identifies a line as a comment line. Same as the *, !, and $* statements.
Calculates the value of the remainder after integer division is performed.
Removes substrings from a dynamic array.
REPEAT causes the loop to start again with the first statement following the LOOP statement.
Replaces all or part of the contents of a dynamic array.
Keywords.detail:
REPLACE (expression, field#, value#, subvalue# { , | ; } replacement)
REPLACE (expression [,field# [,value#]] ; replacement) variable < field# [ ,value# [,subvalue#]] >

Keywords.documentation: The RETURN statement transfers program execution to the caller of a subroutine/function or to a specific label in the program.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the RETURN statement to terminate a subroutine and return control to the calling program or statement.

Keywords.documentation: Returns a value from a user-written function.
Reuses the last value in the shorter of two multivalue lists in a dynamic array operation.
Successively removes elements from a dynamic array, starting from the last element and moving right to left. Extracts successive fields, values, etc., for dynamic array processing.
Keywords.detail: REVREMOVE element FROM dynamic.array SETTING variable

Keywords.documentation: Rewinds the magnetic tape to the beginning of the tape.
Specifies a substring consisting of the last n characters of a string.
Generates a random number between zero and a specified number minus one.
Rolls back all changes made during a transaction. No changes are written to disk
Sends requests to a remote server.
Keywords.detail: RPC.CALL (connection.ID, procedure, #args, MAT arg.list, #values, MAT return.list)

Keywords.documentation: Establishes a connection with a remote server process.
Disconnects from a remote server process.
Adds two string numbers and returns the result as a string number.
Encrypts and saves a security context to a system security file.
Compares two string numbers.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the SCMP function to compare two string numbers and return one of the following three numbers: -1 (less than), 0 (equal), or 1 (greater than). If string.number.1 is less than string.number.2, the result is -1. If they are equal, the result is 0. If string.number.1 is greater than string.number.2, the result is 1. You can use this function in any expression where a string or string number is valid.

Keywords.documentation: Outputs the quotient of the whole division of two integers.

Moves the file pointer by an offset, specified in bytes, relative to the current
position, the beginning of the file, or the end of the file.
Keywords.detail: SEEK file.variable [, offset [, relto]] {THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements}

Keywords.documentation: Moves the command line argument pointer.
The SELECT statement creates a select list of elements in a specified variable for use with the READNEXT statement or to be saved in a list.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use a SELECT statement to create a numbered select list of record IDs from a UniVerse file or a dynamic array. A subsequent READNEXT statement can access this select list, removing one record ID at a time from the list. READNEXT instructions can begin processing the select list immediately.

Keywords.documentation: Assigns the contents of select list 0 to a variable.
Creates select lists from secondary key indexes.
Keywords.detail: SELECTINDEX index [, alt.key] FROM file.variable [TO list.number]

Keywords.documentation: Returns the activity status of a select list.
Store a select list in a numbered select list.
Store a select list in a named list variable.
Writes a block of data to a device that has been opened for I/O using OPENDEV or OPENSEQ.
Keywords.detail: SEND output [:] TO device { THEN statements [ELSE statements] | ELSE statements }

Keywords.documentation: Returns the stored sentence that invoked the current process.
Converts an ASCII character code value to its corresponding numeric value.

Converts each element of a dynamic array from an ASCII character code to a
corresponding numeric value.
Sets the default transaction isolation level for your program.
Keywords.snippetDoc: Use the SET TRANSACTION ISOLATION LEVEL statement to set the default transaction isolation level you need for your program.

Keywords.documentation:
Sets how deeply UniVerse should verify before deciding that a
certificate is not valid.

Allows you to identify which cipher suites should be supported
for the context you specify. It affects the cipher suites and
public key algorithms supported during the SSL/TLS handshake and subsequent data exchanges.
Turns client authentication for a server socket on or off.

Configures the default HTTP settings, including proxy server and port,
buffer size, authentication credential, HTTP version, and request header
values.
Set the default IPv connection for the whole system or for only Socket networks or UVNet
Changes the setting of one or all categories for the current locale.

Loads the private key into a security context so that it can be
used by SSL functions. If the context already had a set private
key, it will be replaced.
Keywords.detail: setPrivateKey(key, format, keyLoc, passPhrase, validate, context, p12pass)

Keywords.documentation:
Generates a random seed file from a series of source files and
sets that file as the default seed file for the security context you supply.
Sets the position of the REMOVE pointer associated with a dynamic array.
Enables you to set additional headers for a request.
Sets the default NLS map for either server or client sockets.

Sets the current value for a socket option associated with a
socket of any type.

Dumps the SSL configuration parameters of a security context
into a readable format.

Generates a digital signature or verifies a signature using the
supplied key.
Keywords.detail: SIGNATURE(algorithm, action, data, dataLoc, key, keyLoc, keyFmt, pass, sigIn, result, p12pass)

Keywords.documentation: Calculates the trigonometric sine of an angle.
Calculates the hyperbolic sine of an expression.

Suspends execution of a BASIC program, pausing for a specified number of
seconds.
Multiplies two string numbers.
Creates a SOAP request and returns a handle to the request.
creates a secure SOAP request and returns a handle to the request.
Retrieves the default SOAP settings, such as the SOAP version.
Parses the response data from SOAPSubmitRequest into a dynamic array of SOAP Fault components.
Gets a specific response header after issuing a SOAP request.
Outputs the SOAP request, in XML format, to a string or to a file.
Define default SOAP settings, such as the SOAP version. By default, the SOAP version is 1.1, although you can specify version 1.2.
